File.Title: Connections of the Subthalamic Nucleus With Ventral Striatopallidal Parts of the Basal Ganglia in the Rat
File.Authors: HENK J. GROENEWEGEN AND HENK W. BERENDSE

Abstract.S: The present study was undertaken to establish the precise anatomical relationship of the subthalamic nucleus (STh) with limbic lobe-afferented parts of the basal ganglia in the rat.

The anterograde tracer Phaseolus uulgaris-leucoagglutinin (PHA-L), injected in the STh, the globus pallidus, the ventral pallidum, the ventral striatum, and the parafascicular thalamic nucleus, and the retrograde tracers Fluoro-Gold (FG) and cholera toxin B (CTb), injected in the globus pallidus, the ventral pallidum, the ventral striatum, and the ventral mesencephalon, were used for this purpose.
The results of these tracing experiments confirm the general notion of reciprocal connections between the STh and pallidal areas.
Thus the dorsomedial part of the STh is connected with the subcommisural ventral pallidum, whereas a more ventral and lateral part of the medial STh is related to the medial globus pallidus.

The lateral hypothalamic area, directly adjacent to the STh, containing neurons with a morphology quite similar to those in the STh, projects to parts of the ventral pallidum related to the olfactory tubercle.
The reciprocal projection from this pallidal area to subthalamic regions appears to be very sparse.
The medial STh sends strong projections to the medial part of the entopeduncular nucleus and the adjacent lateral hypothalamic area.
Sparser projections from the medial STh reach the rostra1 and medial part of the caudate-putamen and the nucleus accumbens.
The nucleus accumbens sends a very sparse projection back to the medial STh.
The projections of the medial STh to the ventral mesencephalon appear also to be topographically organized.

The lateral hypothalamus and a few cells in the most medial part of the STh project to the ventral tegmental area, whereas progressively more lateral parts of the ventral mesencephalon, in particular the substantia nigra, receive input from successively more lateral and caudal parts of the STh.
In addition, a number of STh fibers reach the midbrain extrapyramidal area.

The lateral part of the parafascicular thalamic nucleus projects to the lateral part of the STh, whereas parafascicular neurons medial to the fasciculus retroflexus project to the dorsomedial portion of the STh.

The medial part of the STh and the adjacent lateral hypothalamus are intimately connected with limbic parts of the basal ganglia in a way similar and parallel to the connections of the lateral STh with motor-related parts of the basal ganglia.
These findings suggest a role for the STh in nonmotor functions of the basal ganglia.

Introduction.S: The subthalamic nucleus (STh), a small nuclear mass located just dorsal to the cerebral peduncle in the caudal part of the diencephalon, is generally considered to be part of the motor system.
Dysfunctioning of this nucleus can lead to a hyperkinetic syndrome that is known as (hemi)ballism.

Although there are some species differences, in all mammals studied the main projections from the STh reach the external and internal (entopeduncular nucleus in cats and rodents) segments of the globus pallidus, the substantia nigra, and the pedunculopontine tegmental nucleus (Nauta and Cole, '78; Ricardo, '80; Carpenter et al., '81; Jackson and Crossman, '81, '83; Kita and Kitai, '87).

In turn, the STh receives fibers predominantly from the external segment of the globus pallidus and the motor cortex (Kunzle and Akert, '77; Kunzle, '78; Hartmann-Von Monakow et al., '79; Carpenter et al., '81; Afsharpour, '85) and to a lesser degree from the parafascicular thalamic nucleus (Sugimoto et al., '83; Sugimot0 and Hattori, '83) and the pedunculopontine tegmental nucleus (Graybiel, '77; Nomura et al., '80; Carpenter et al., '81; Hammond et al., '83).

In the 1980s it became increasingly clear that extensive parts of the basal ganglia are involved in the processing of information from limbic structures, in particular the hippocampus and the amygdala (Heimer and Wilson, '75).
The connectional organization of these limbic lobe-afferented parts of the basal ganglia largely parallels the circuitry of the rest of the basal ganglia (Haber et al., '85).

In the rat, it has been shown that the limbic striatum encompasses the nucleus accumbens, the striatal elements of the olfactory tubercle, and the ventromedial and caudal parts of the caudate-putamen.

This designation is primarily based on the distribution in the ventral striatum of inputs from the hippocampus, the amygdala, and limbic diencephalic and mesencephalic structures (Heimer and Wilson, '75; Groenewegen et al., '82, '87; Nauta, '86).

The efferent connections of the ventral striatum are distributed to pallidal structures that occupy the medial region of the main body of the globus pallidus and an adjacent area underneath the anterior commissure that has been designated as the ventral pallidum (Heimer and Wilson, '75; Nauta et al., '78; Haber and Nauta, '83).

The latter area encompasses a region directly ventral to the anterior commissure, i.e., the subcommissural part of the ventral pallidum, and fingerlike rostra1 extensions of this region into the deep layers of the olfactory tubercle.
Like its dorsal, nonlimbic counterpart, the ventral pallidum sends fibers to the thalamus, the ventral mesencephalon, and the STh (Haber et al., '85; Nauta, '86).
The projection from the ventral part of the pallidal complex to the STh has been considered as a route by which ventral striatopallidal pathways reach the motor system (Nauta, '86).
Apart from the ventral pallidal input to the STh, very little is known about any further relations of this nucleus with the limbic lobe-innervated parts of the basal ganglia.

Recently, it has been shown that the primate STh is a rather differentiated structure with respect to its afferent and efferent connections and that functionally different subsectors may exist (e.g., Parent and Smith, '87).
The main purpose of the present study in the rat was to establish the exact anatomical relationship of the STh with limbic lobe-related parts of the basal ganglia and the midbrain tegmentum.
Therefore, injections of anterograde tracers were placed in the STh, the ventral striatum, the globus pallidus, and the ventral pallidum.
Retrograde tracers were injected in the ventral tegmental area and the adjacent substantia nigra and in the globus pallidus, the ventral pallidum, and the ventral striatum.
Additional data were obtained from injections of anterograde tracers in the caudal thalamus.

The results of our experiments show that the medial portion of the STh and the directly adjacent region of the lateral hypothalamus are intricately connected with parts of the basal ganglia that project to and receive inputs from limbic structures, i.e., the ventral pallidum, the olfactory tubercle, and the ventral tegmental area.
This may imply that, apart from its prevalent motor role, the STh is also involved in the processing of limbic information.

Methods.S: MATERIALS AND METHODS
All experiments were done with female Wistar rats (180220 g body wt.).
Prior to surgery the animals were anesthetized by an intramuscular injection of a mixture of Ketamine and Rompun (4:3, 1 ml/kg).
After the appropriate survival time, the rats were deeply re-anesthetized with an intraperitoneal injection of pentobarbital (NembutalR) and transcardially perfused to fix the brain.

Stereotaxic coordinates for the injections in the subthalamic nucleus (STh; n = 2), the ventral pallidum, the medial part of the globus pallidus, the olfactory tubercle (n = 13), the ventral striatum (n = lo), and the parafascicular thalamic nucleus (n = 4) were determined by using the atlas of Paxinos and Watson ('86) as a reference.

Injections of 2.5 % Phaseolus uulgaris-leucoagglutinin (Gerfen and Sawchenko, '84; PHA-L; Vector Laboratories), dissolved in 0.05 M Tris buffer at pH 7.4, were made by applying a 5 PA positive pulsed current (7 sec on/7 sec off CCS-3 constant current source Midgard) to the PHA-L solution in a glass micropipette (internal diameter 10-20 pm) for 15-30 minutes.

The animals were allowed to survive for 7-14 days and perfused transcardially with 200 ml saline, followed by 500 ml fixative containing 4% paraformaldehyde and 0.05% glutaraldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.4) over a 15-30-minute period.

Following 2-4 hours postfixation, in this fixative, the brains were stored overnight at 4°C in 30% phosphate-buffered sucrose, subsequently cut at 40 pm on a freezing microtome, and collected in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.4).
Sections to be immunoprocessed with anti-PHA-L were first prerinsed three times (15 min) in 0.05 M Tris-buffered saline (pH 8.6) with 0.5% Triton X-100 (TBS-T).
Incubation in rabbit-anti-PHA-L (1:2,000; E-Y Labs) in TBS-T lasted for 36-60 hours at 4°C.
To visualize the PHA-L, the peroxidase-antiperoxidase (PAP) method according to Sternberger ( 79) was used.
Prior to the incubation with the second antibody, the sections were rinsed 3 x 15 minutes in TBS-T.

The sections were then incubated in swineantirabbit whole serum ( ~ 4 0 Nordic ; Immunochemicals, Tilburg, The Netherlands) for 60 minutes (20°C) in TBS-T and subsequently transferred to rabbit peroxidase-antiperoxidase (1:800; Nordic Immunochemicals) in TBS-T for 60 minutes at room temperature.
After rinsing 3 x 15 minutes in Tris/HCl, pH 7.6, the sections were processed with diaminobenzidine (DAB; 50 mg in 100 ml Tris/HCl, pH 7.6).
The DAB solution contained 35 fil 30% H,0,/100 ml, and the incubation lasted 15-45 minutes.
After a thorough rinse the sections were mounted.
Half of the sections were counterstained with Cresyl violet, whereas the remaining sections were left unstained.
Labeled fibers and terminals were plotted by using a drawing tube on a standard Zeiss microscope.
Retrograde tracing with Fluoro-Gold (FG)

In a separate set of experiments, injections of the fluorescent tracer Fluoro-Gold (Schmued and Fallon, 86; FG; 2% in acetate buffer; Fluorochrome Inc.) were placed in different pallidal areas of six rats and in the ventral tegmental area of another six rats.
The injections were made iontophoretically through glass micropipettes (25-40 fim internal tip diameter) by using a positive-pulsed 10 @A current (7 sec on/ sec off) for 5-15 minutes.
Following a survival period of 7-17 days, the animals were perfused with 100 ml saline, followed by 750 ml 4% paraformaldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer, pH 7.4.

The brains were postfixed for 30 minutes to 2 hours in the same fixative, stored overnight at 4°C either in 30% phosphate-buffered sucrose or in a mixture of 20% glycerine and 2% dimethyl sulfoxide in distilled water, and cut on a freezing microtome at 40 pm.
Sections were then mounted, air dried, xylene cleared, coverslipped with Entallan, and examined under a Zeiss IV F fluorescence miroscope, using filter-mirror system 01 (365 nm).
Retrograde tracing of cholera toxin B (CTb)

In 10 rats injections of the tracer choleratoxin B (Ericson and Blomqvist, 88; CTb; List Biochemical Laboratories) were placed in the ventral striatum and in 10 rats in the ventral tegmental area and the substantia nigra.

The tracer, in a 1 % solution containing 1 M Tris, 4 M NaCl, 0.02 M Na, EDTA and 0.06 M NaN,, pH 7.5, was injected by means of air pressure through glass micropipettes (external tip diameter 10-25 pm; injection volume 0.2-0.5 pl per injection).

The animals were allowed to survive for 6-11 days and were then perfused with 150 ml saline and 500 ml of a fixative containing 4% paraformaldehyde, 15 % picric acid and 0.05 % glutaraldehyde in phosphate buffer (pH 7.4).
Following one to two hours postfixation in the same fixative, the brains were stored overnight at 4OC in a mixture of 20% glycerol and 2 % dimethylsulfoxide in distilled water.
Sections were cut at 40 pm on a freezing microtome and collected in 0.05 M Tris-buffered saline (pH 7.6).

Every second section was incubated in a sequence of goat anti-CTb (18 hrs; 1:5,000, List Biochemical Laboratories), donkey antigoat whole serum (60 min; 150, Nordic Immunology, The Netherlands), and goat peroxidase-antiperoxidase (60 min; PAP, 1:400, Nordic Immunology, The Netherlands).
All antisera were dissolved in TBS-T (see above).
Prior to incubation, the sections were rinsed three times (15 min) in TBS-T.
Following incubation, the sections were rinsed and subsequently processed with Ni-enhanced diaminobenzidine (DAB, 12.5 mg in 25 mlO.1 M phosphate buffer, pH 7.4 with 1 ml 15% ammonium-Ni-sulfate).
The rest of the incubation procedure was similar to that described for PHA-L tracing.
Half of the incubated sections were counterstained with Cresyl violet prior to coverslipping.

Results.S: Injections of PHA - L in pallidal structures .

TTE.S: Injections of PHA - L were placed in eight rats in various parts of the ventral pallidum , in three rats in the olfactory tubercle , and in two rats medially in the rostral part of the globus pallidus .

Following the injection in the ventral pallidum in rat RP - 83415 ( Fig . lA ) , an area of dense termination can be observed in the dorsomedial part of the subthalamic nucleus ( STh ; Fig . 1B ) throughout its rostrocaudal extent .
Terminal fibers are also present in the lateral hypothalamus in an area immediately medial to the STh ( Fig .IB).
After an injection of PHA - L medially in the globus pallidus ( RP - 84114 ; Fig .
IC ) , the terminals in the STh occupy a more lateral and ventral position in the medial part of the nucleus ( Fig .
ID) when compared with the previous case.
There are only very few fibers and terminals in the lateral hypothalamus medial to the STh .

Injections of PHA - L in the olfactory tubercle do not result in any anterograde labeling in the STh , even in cases in which at the injection site both medium - size , striatallike , and larger pallidallike neurons were labeled ( RP - 85050 ) .

In such cases , anterogradely PHA - L - labeled axons can be followed through the medial forebrain bundle to terminate in the lateral hypothalamus at the level of the rostral part of the STh ( Fig . 1E ) .

Compared to the density of termination in the STh in cases of injections in the ventral pallidum and the globus pallidus , the termination in the lateral hypothalamic area following injections in the olfactory tubercle is rather sparse .
Injections of PHA - L in the subthalamic nucleus .
In two rats an injection of PHA - L was placed in the medial part of the STh .

In both cases densely stained , small neurons are present in the center of the injection site in the STh , but there are also a small number of labeled neurons along the injection tract in the area immediately dorsal to the STh , i . e . , the zona incerta ( e . g . , RP - 84149 ; Fig . 2A ) .
In case RP - 84149 labeled fibers ascend through the lateral hypothalamic area , giving off sparse branches with varicosities and terminal boutons .
At the level of the entopeduncular nucleus a dense terminal field is observed just medial to this internal segment of the globus pallidus in the lateral hypothalamus ( Fig . 2D ) .

Farther rostrally in the basal forebrain , an extremely dense fiber and terminal field is present in the subcommissural part of the ventral pallidum ( Fig . 2B , C ) and in continuity with it , in the medial part of the main body of the globus pallidus ( Fig . 2C ) .
In the ventral pallidum , the density of terminations rapidly decreases in rostral and ventral directions , and no fibers or terminals are found in the pallidal regions of the olfactory tubercle .
Above the anterior commissure , a dense accumulation of terminals is found not only in the medial globus pallidus but also medial to it between the fiber bundles of the internal capsule ( Fig .
ZC,E).
In dorsal and lateral directions, the density of terminals rapidly diminishes.

However , in particular in more caudal regions of the globus pallidus , a large contingent of fibers courses laterally and apparently terminates in the lateral part of the globus pallidus where it borders the caudate - putamen complex .
Such lateral terminations are most prominent ventrally in the globus pallidus ( Fig . 2E ) .
The fiber and terminal density in pallidal regions is considerably less in the second case with an injection of PHA - L in the medial part of the STh ( RP - 84173 ) .
The distribution of labeled fibers and terminals , however , is essentially rather similar to that described for the previous case .

In both cases of injections of PHA - L in the STh , a considerable number of retrogradely labeled neurons are present in dorsal and ventral pallidal regions where they lie intermingled with the terminal fiber plexus of anterogradely labeled subthalamic afferents .
In numerous occasions , labeled fibers carrying varicosities are seen in close apposition with the perikarya or the proximal dendrites of retrogradely labeled neurons ( Fig . 3 ) .
Injections of Fluoro-Gold in pallidal regions.
In case RF - 87219 an iontophoretic injection of FG was placed in the subcommissural part of the ventral pallidum .
The center of the injection site , as identified by a small locus of intense fluorescence , is located just beneath the posterior limb of the anterior commissure ( Fig . 4A ) .
The periphery of the injection site , which has a diameter of about 2 - 3 mm , is characterized by strongly fluorescent neuronal and glial cells against a diffuse fluorescent background labeling .
In the STh a large number of retrogradely labeled , intensely fluorescent neurons are present in its medial one - third .
In the dorsomedial part of the nucleus , virtually all cells are strongly fluorescent , whereas laterally and ventrally the labeled neurons rapidly diminish in number ( Fig . 4B , C ) .
Scattered labeled cells are found between the fascicles of the cerebral peduncle ( Fig . 4C ) ventral to the STh and in the medially adjacent lateral hypothalamic region ( Fig . 4B ) .
An injection of FG , placed more ventrally and rostrally in the basal forebrain , includes the deep layers of the caudal part of the olfactory tubercle ( RF - 87157 ).
Following this injection , relatively few retrogradely labeled neurons are found in the medial part of the STh .
Most of the fluorescent neurons in the nucleus are seen in the dorsomedial corner , whereas more ventrally and laterally cells are more dispersed and less intensely fluorescent ( Fig . 4E , F ) .
Immediately medial to the STh , labeled neurons are present in the lateral hypothalamic area .
As can be appreciated from Figure 4F , the labeled neurons in this area are less densely packed , but regarding their size and morphology clearly resemble the labeled neurons in the STh .
In rat RF - 87450 an injection of FG was placed in the medial part of the globus pallidus .
The injection site does not extend into the ventral pallidum .
Retrogradely labeled neurons in the STh are present in the medial half of the nucleus , but are located more ventrally and laterally than in the previous cases .
Moreover , the extreme dorsomedial part of the nucleus remains free of retrograde labeling ( Fig . 4D ) .
Injections of PHA - L in the subthalamic nucleus .

In both cases of PHA - L injections in the STh ( RP - 84149, RP - 84170 ) , sparse labeling of fibers and terminals could be observed in the striatum , in particular in rostra1 and medial parts of the caudate - putamen complex and in the lateral two - thirds of the nucleus accumbens ( Fig . 5A , B ) .
Injections of cholera toxin B ( CTb ) in the ventral striatum .

The injections of CTb in the ventral striatum cover in most cases a relatively large area ( 1 - 2 mm in diameter ) , such that either the medial or the lateral half of the nucleus accumbens is included in the injection site .
Following all injections retrogradely labeled neurons are observed in the STh .

For example , in rat RC - 89149 with an injection of CTb laterally in the ventral striatum ( Fig . 5C ) , a small number of granularly labeled neurons is present in the medial one - third of the STh ( Fig . 5D ) .
It must be noted that these neurons contain only perikaryal labeling and that the dendrites remain free of label.
This is in contrast to the extensive dendritic labeling of neurons in other parts of the brain following CTb injections ( present observations ; Ericson and Blomqvist , ' 88 ) .
Apart from the retrograde labeling in the STh , anterograde fiber labeling is present in the lateral hypothalamus , just ventromedial to the STh ( Fig . 5D ) .
A few of these fibers appear to enter the STh , indicating the existence of projections from the ventral striatum to this nucleus .
Injections of PHA - L in the ventral striaturn .
Of a large collection of experiments with PHA - L injections in the ventral striatum , only a small number of cases showed anterograde labeling in the STh .
The fibers from the ventral striatum descend through the lateral hypothalamus .
At the level of the posterior hypothalamus , they course just medial to the cerebral peduncle skirting the most ventromedial part of the STh .
In a number of cases , a few individual fibers are found in the medial part of the STh ( Fig . 5E , F ) .

Results.S: Relationship of the subthalamic nucleus with the mesencephalon

TTE.S: Following the injection of PHA - L in the medial part of the STh in rat RP - 84149, a dense terminal field is found in the medial two - thirds of the pars reticulata , whereas the pars compacta of the substantia nigra is less densely labeled ( Fig . 6A , B ) .
Terminal labeling is relatively sparse in the ventral tegmental area ( Fig . 6C ) .
Furthermore , labeled fibers traverse the retrorubral and central tegmental fields of the mesencephalon in a lateral and caudal curve .
As judged from the relatively smooth appearance of the PHA - L labeled fibers , there are only few terminations along the course of these fibers .
More caudally a sparsely labeled terminal field can be observed that is located just dorsal to the superior cerebellar peduncle at the level of the trochlear nucleus ( Fig . 6D ) .
This area coincides with the midbrain extrapyramidal area as recently described by Rye et al. ('87).
A few fibers extend medially and terminate in the ventrolateral part of the central grey substance .

Results.S: In order to study a possible topographical organization in the projections from the STh to the ventral mesencephalon , a number of experiments with injections of FG or CTb in the ventral tegmental area and the substantia nigra were carried out .

TTE.S: Following injections of CTb that involve the ventral tegmental area with only minor inclusion of the medial part of the substantia nigra , retrogradely labeled neurons in the STh are located in its medial part ( Fig . 6E ) .
It must be noted that the density of anterograde and retrograde labeling in the adjacent lateral hypothalamic area far exceeds that of the labeling in the STh ( Fig . 6E ) .
Injections that were placed more laterally in the substantia nigra result in retrograde labeling in most of the STh ( Fig . 6F ) .
Following such injections , there is in addition extensive anterograde and retrograde labeling in the dorsally adjacent zona incerta .

In experiments with PHA - L injections in the midline and the intralaminar nuclei of the thalamus , which were placed in the course of a parallel study ( Berendse et al . , ' 88 ; Berendse and Groenewegen , ' 90a ) , the projections from the thalamus to the STh could be examined .
In particular , injections of PHA - L in the parafascicular nucleus result in anterograde labeling in the STh .
Injections that involve the portion of the parafascicular nucleus located lateral to the fasciculus retroflexus give rise to labeling in the lateral part of the STh ( Fig . 7A , B ) .

Injections placed medial to the fasciculus retroflexus that involve , among others , the medial part of the parafascicular nucleus , result in labeled fibers and terminals in the dorsomedial part of the STh ( Fig . 7C , D ) .
Anterograde labeling was absent from the STh following PHA - L injections in the same caudal thalamic area that did not involve the medial part of the parafascicular nucleus .

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION
The main data of the present study are summarized in Figure 8.

Combining the results of the anterograde and retrograde tracing experiments, it can be concluded that the dorsomedial part of the STh has strong reciprocal connections with the subcommissural part of the ventral pallidum.

The same part of the STh sends weaker projections to the ventral tegmental area and adjacent parts of the substantia nigra and to a more caudal midbrain region, i.e., the midbrain extrapyramidal area (Rye et al., '87).
It further receives thalamic inputs from the medial part of the parafascicular nucleus.

The region of the medial STh, directly ventral and lateral to the above-mentioned dorsomedial portion of the STh, is reciprocally connected with the medial part of the main body of the glohus pallidus.

Projections from more lateral parts of the STh terminate more laterally and ventrally in the substantia nigra than those from the medial part and, like the latter, also extend into the midbrain extrapyramidal area (Fig. 8).

The results of the PHA-L anterograde tracing experiments show that the medial STh has additional projections to the medial part of the entopeduncular nucleus and the directly adjacent region of the lateral hypothalamic area and to a lateral and ventral zone of the globus pallidus.
The present experiments do not allow conclusions with respect to a topography in these projections.
Finally, the lateral hypothalamic region medially adjacent to the STh has connections, albeit weak, with the pallidal elements of the olfactory tubercle.
Before dealing in more detail with the connections of the medial STh, the tracing methods used by us in this study are briefly discussed.
Methodological considerations
The advantages and limitations of the use of Phaseolus uulgaris-leucoagglutinin (PHA-L) have been amply discussed in the literature (Gerfen and Sawchenko, '84; Groenewegen and Wouterlood, '90).
Choleratoxin subunit B (CTb) has been introduced only recently as a retrograde neuroanatomical tracer (Ericson and Blomqvist, '88) and therefore deserves some discussion.
Choleratoxin B is transported both anterogradely and retrogradely, but the anterograde transport is generally weaker and in its quality of labeling neuronal structures is not comparable with PHA-L.
The main advantage of CTb as a retrograde tracer is its superior sensitivity and the excellent retrograde filling of the dendritic arborizations (Ericson and Rlomqvist, '88).
In the present study the very weak projections from the STh to the striatum could indeed be shown with CTh.
The main disadvantages of the CTb technique are that the dimensions of the injection site are difficult to control and that the tracer is taken up by passing fibers.
However, both problems do not affect the interpretation of the results of the present experiments in which CTb was used.
Pallidal connections

The results of previous studies have shown that the most prominent fiber connections of the STh are established with pallidal structures (e.g., Nauta and Cole, '78; Ricardo, '80; Carpenter et al., '81; Kita and Kitai, '87).
In concurrence with these studies, the present data indicate that the densest projections from the medial STh reach the ventral pallidum and the medial part of the entopeduncular nucleus.
Furthermore, the lateral hypothalamic area medially adjacent to the entopeduncular nucleus receives an even denser termination from the medial STh than the entopeduncular nucleus.
This finding underscores the previously expressed notion that this area is continuous with and, in its connectivity, very similar to the entopeduncular nucleus (cf.
Heimer et al., '85).
Like the entopeduncular nucleus, neurons in this region of the lateral hypothalamus project to the lateral habenula (Herkenham and Nauta, '77).

The same hypothalamic region receives input also from the ventral striatum and has immunohistochemical characteristics comparable to those of the entopeduncular nucleus (Nauta et al., '78; Groenewegen and Russchen, '84; Haber et al., '90).
The present findings of a projection from the medial STh to the lateral hypothalamus adjacent to the entopeduncular nucleus further confirms the internal pallidal nature of this area.
Whether the latter region indeed represents the internal segment of the limbic-related ventral pallidum cannot be concluded only from the existing evidence.
Physiological and behavioral data are needed to further explore this possibility.

It is also important to note here that the subcommissural ventral or limbic pallidum has a number of characteristics that resemble those of both the internal and external segments of the globus pallidus (cf.
Heimer et al., 85; Nauta, 86).
Therefore, it is unclear whether a separation in internal and external segments can be made within the limbic-related parts of the pallidal complex, as in the dorsally located globus pallidus.
The present results indicate that there is a rather strict topography in the reciprocal pallidosubthalamic connections involving the medial STh.

In particular, the results of the anterograde (PHA-L) and retrograde tracer injections in the subcommissural part of the ventral pallidum and of those in the medial sector of the globus pallidus show that these distinct parts of the pallidal complex communicate with distinct parts of the medial STh (Fig. 8).

As a result of the circumstance that following the injections of PHA-L in the STh pallidal neurons are retrogradely labeled, it was observed that anterogradely labeled subthalamopallidal fibers make close contact with these retrogradely labeled pallidal cells or with their dendrites.
This emphasizes the reciprocity of the connections.

The fact that injections of PHA-L in the olfactory tubercle, in which large pallidal neurons are included, give rise to anterograde labeling of fibers and terminals in the lateral hypothalamic area adjacent to the STh and that injections of retrograde tracers in the olfactory tubercle result in labeled neurons in the same hypothalamic region, concurs with the reciprocity in the pallidosubthalamic connections.
This implies that a population of neurons outside the borders of the STh have connectional characteristics comparable to those of subthalamic neurons.

An argument in favor of the notion that neurons lying outside the STh proper belong to the same neuronal system is the similarity in morphology of the retrogradely labeled neurons in the lateral hypothalamus at the level of the STh following olfactory tubercle injections and the retrogradely labeled cells in the STh after injections in the ventral pallidum (cf. also Kita et al., 83).
A difference is that in the STh the neurons are more closely packed.

Furthermore, it is of interest to note that a small number of subthalamic cells projecting to the globus pallidus are situated amidst the fiber bundles of the cerebral peduncle, and therefore also lie outside the borders of the STh.

Whether the lateral hypothalamic neurons close to the STh may indeed be considered subthalamic neurons awaits further knowledge of the synaptology and the physiological characteristics of these cells.

Seemingly in contrast with the above-discussed topography in the pallidosubthalamic connections is the finding that PHA-L injections in the medial STh result in a rather widespread anterograde labeling in the pallidal complex.
However, this is probably due to the fact that even when PHA-L is used as the tracer, the injection sites in a small nucleus such as the STh are relatively large.

Another observation that bears discussion is the presently observed projection from the medial part of the STh to a strip in the ventral and lateral parts of the globus pallidus at the border with the caudate-putamen complex.
A lateral strip of subthalamic terminals in the globus pallidus has also been reported by Kita and Kitai ('87) following lateral injections in STh.

As suggested by these authors, inputs from all parts of the STh might converge in this lateral band of the globus pallidus, whereas the subthalamopallidal fibers to more medial parts of the pallidal complex are topographically organized (as discussed above).

The striatopallidal projection system has also been shown, on the one hand, to be highly topographically organized and, on the other, to contain a nontopographical component, such that divergent areas of the striatum project in an overlapping manner to a lateral strip of the globus pallidus bordering the caudateputamen complex (Chang et al., '81; Wilson and Phelan, '82; Gerfen, '85).
Presumably, the lateral strip of subthalamic projections in the globus pallidus overlaps with these nontopographically organized striatopallidal projections.
Not only in the rat, but also in the primate a banded organization of the subthalamopallidal projections has been described (Nauta and Cole, '78; Parent et al., '89).
Striatal connections
The present PHA-L antrograde tracing experiments demonstrate, in agreement with the observations of Kita and Kitai ('87), the existence of a projection from the STh to the striatum.
The fibers originate in the medial part of the STh and terminate predominantly in the rostral and medial parts of the caudate-putamen complex and in the lateral part of the nucleus accumbens.
The projection to the ventral striatum is confirmed by the results of injections of the sensitive tracer CTb.

Apparently, it is modest in volume since following injections of this tracer in the ventral striatum the number of retrogradely neurons in the STh is very small and the cells are only weakly labeled even though the injections are relatively large.

The results obtained from a large collection of PHA-L tracing experiments with injections of the tracer in the ventral striatum indicate that the connection from the STh to this part of the striatum is reciprocated.
As judged from the number of fibers that enter the STh following PHA-L injections in the ventral striatum, this return pathway is also not extensive in the rat.

It may therefore be concluded that, although a reciprocal connection between the STh and the striatum does exist in the rat, this pathway is much less prevalent than in cats and monkeys (rat: Kita and Kitai, '87; present study; cat: Beckstead, '83; Royce and Laine, '84; monkey: Nauta and Cole, '78; Parent and Smith, '87).
Connections with the thalamus
Inputs from the thalamus to the STh have been shown previously in the rat and the cat with anterograde autoradiographic tracing techniques (Sugimoto et al., '83; Sugimoto and Hattori, '83).
The results of the present PHA-L tracing experiments confirm that these projections to the STh originate in the parafascicular nucleus of the caudal thalamus.
In none of our cases with PHA-L injections in more rostral parts of the midline and intralaminar thalamic nuclei could anterograde labeling be observed in the STh (unpublished observations).
Our data demonstrate that, like the pallidosubthalamic connections, the thalamosubthalamic pathway is topographically organized.
The most medial part of the parafascicular nucleus, located medially to the fasciculus retroflexus, projects to the dorsomedial part of the STh.

This part of the parafascicular thalamic nucleus also sends fibers to the nucleus accumhens (Berendse and Groenewegen, '90a), which, via a pathway leading through the subcommissural ventral pallidum, is related to the medial STh.

The largest part of the parafascicular nucleus, located lateral to the fasciculus retroflexus projects to the more lateral regions of the STh and to extensive areas of the dorsal striatum (Beckstead, '84; Berendse and Groenewegen, '90a), which, in turn, indirectly via the globus pallidus, can influence the lateral STh.
Connections with the brainstem

In agreement with previous studies, the results of our anterograde tracing experiments with injections of PHA-L in the STh show that the main descending projections of this nucleus are directed to the pars reticulata of the substantia nigra (Nauta and Cole, '78; Ricardo, '80; Carpenter et al., '81; Gerfen et al., '82; Kita and Kitai, '87).

Whereas Ricardo ('80) showed that injections of tritiated amino acids in lateral parts of the STh give rise to anterograde labeling ventrally in the pars reticulata, close to the cerebral peduncle, the present results show that the projections from the medial STh reach more dorsal strata of the pars reticulata, close to the pars compacta.
It thus appears that in these projections a mediolateral axis in the STh corresponds to a dorsoventral axis in the substantia nigra (cf. also Kita and Kitai, '87).

As has previously been demonstrated by other authors (Ricardo, '80; Mintz et al., '86; Kita and Kitai, '87), our results also show that the pars compacta of the substantia nigra receives an input from the STh.

In line with the above-discussed involvement of the medial STh in limbicrelated circuits, additional projections from this part of the nucleus are directed to the limbic-related ventral tegmental area.

It is therefore possible that the medial part of the STh, through its projections to the dopaminergic cells in the ventral tegmental area and the adjacent pars compacta of the substantia nigra influences the ascending mesolimbic dopamine pathways, which, among others, distribute to the ventral striatum.

Projections from the STh to more caudal midbrain regions, in particular to the region of the pedunculopontine tegmental nucleus, have also been described previously (Nauta and Cole, '78; Hammond et al., '83; Jackson and Crossman, '81, '83; Kita and Kitai, '87).
In our present description, we have followed the more recent subdivision and nomenclature of the midbrain tegmentum by Rye et al. ('87).
According to this scheme, the relatively sparse projections from the medial part of the STh terminate in the midbrain extrapyramidal area dorsal and lateral to the superior cerebellar peduncle.

It has recently been shown by Lee et al. ('88) that the return fibers from the midbrain tegmentum to the STli also originate for the most part in the midbrain extrapyramidal area and only a very small percentage from cholinergic cells in the pedunculopontine tegmental nucleus.
The subthalamic nucleus and the circuitry of the basal ganglia
It has long been recognized that the connections between the striatum, the pallidal complex, and substantia nigra are topographically organized.
The results of the present and other recent studies provide evidence that the connections of the STh also fit into this topographical pattern.

For instance, the nucleus accumbens of the ventral striatum projects to the subcommissural part of the ventral pallidum and to the lateral hypothalamic area adjacent to the entopeduncular nucleus (Nauta et al., '78; Groenewegen and Russchen, '84).
These two pallidal regions are in turn connected with a small dorsomedial portion of the STh (present study).
It was observed by us that there is also a direct pathway from the nucleus accumbens to the medial STh.

A second system of striatopallidosubthalamic connections is formed by the projections from the ventromedial part of the caudato-putamen to the medial parts of the globus pallidus (Gerfen, '85) and the entopeduncular nucleus (unpublished observations) and the reciprocal connections between these regions and lateral and ventral parts of the medial STh (present results).

Thirdly, as demonstrated by Gerfen ('85) and Fink-Jensen and Mikkelsen ('89), the more lateral and dorsal parts of the caudato-putamen project to lateral and dorsal parts of the globus pallidus and to the lateral part of the entopeduncular nucleus.
The area in the STh that maintains reciprocal connections with the latter two regions comprises the lateral two-thirds of the nucleus (Ricardo, '80; Kita and Kitai, '87).

As first documented by Nauta and Domesick ('79) and Domesick ('81)' the organization in the projections from the striatum to the substantia nigra is such that ventral regions of the striatum, including the nucleus accumhens, project to dorsal zones of the substantia nigra, whereas dorsal regions of the striatum project to ventral zones of the substantia nigra.
In the present study it was found that the projections from medial-to-lateral STh are also arranged along a dorsoventral axis in the substantia nigra.

Because, as discussed above, the medial and lateral parts of the STh are related to ventral and dorsal regions of the striatum, respectively, this means that the topography in the subthalamonigral fibers is in register with that in the striatonigral projections (see also Kita and Kitai, '87).

A further interesting feature is that the projections of the lateral and medial parts of the thalamic parafascicular nucleus to the striatum and STh terminate in areas that are mutually interconnected, either directly or by way of the pallidal complex.

The areas that are targeted by the fibers from the lateral parts of the parafascicular nucleus are the dorsolateral region of the caudate-putamen and the lateral STh, whereas the medial part of the parafascicular nucleus distributes its fibers to the medial region of the caudateputamen, the lateral part of the nucleus accumbens, and the medial STh (Berendse and Groenewegen, '90a).

Both in rats (Afsharpour, '85) and in monkeys (Kunzle and Akert, '77; Kunzle, '78; Hartmann-Von Monakow et al., '79)' it has been demonstrated that the motor and premotor cortices have projections to the STh.

Afsharpour ('85), using anterograde tracing of tritiated amino acids in the rat, described a topographical organization in the projections of the frontal agranular cortex and the zone of overlap of the motor and the sensory cortical areas to the STh.
The rostra1 part of the medial agranular cortex projects to the ventral two-thirds of the medial STh.
The dorsomedial part of the STh remains free of labeling following the cortical injections placed by Afsharpour ('85).
This may indicate that the dorsomedial STh is innervated by frontal cortical regions that were not studied by Afsharpour, i.e., the medial and lateral prefrontal cortical areas.

Preliminary results of experiments with PHA-L injections in these parts of the prefrontal cortex indeed show that the dorsomedial part of the STh is innervated by the prefrontal cortex (Berendse and Groenewegen, 'gob).
These same cortical areas, additionally, have indirect access to the medial STh through the ventral striatopallidal system.
Functional interpret a tions
The role of the subthalamic nucleus (STh) in behavior is thought to be primarily in the realm of the motor system.

This suggestion is based on the intimate anatomical relationship of the STh with primarily motor-related parts of the basal ganglia and with the motor cortex, and concurs with experimental and clinical observations that lesions or pharmacological manipulations of the STh result in pronounced motor disturbances, i.e., (hemi)ballistic symptoms (Martin, '27; Whittier and Mettler, '49; Carpenter et al., '50; Crossman, '87).

However, the present and previous (Ricardo, '80; Haber et al., '85; Kita and Kitai, '87) anatomical tracing studies have provided evidence that the STh also has connections with the ventral pallidum, which through projections from the ventral striatum is under the influence of limbic structures.

Moreover, it could presently be shown that the medial STh has additional connections with other limbic-innervated parts of the basal ganglia, such as the ventral tegmental area, the lateral hypothalamus at the level of the entopeduncular nucleus, and the ventral striatum.
Our results further indicate that the connections of the lateral hypothalamus directly medial to the STh has characteristics very similar to those of the STh itself.

The conclusion that the medial STh is intricately connected with the ventral striatopallidal parts of the basal ganglia is important since, contrary to earlier reports that the subthalamic output is inhibitory and GABAergic (Rouzaire-Dubois et al., '83), it has now been demonstrated that the projections of the STh to the pallidal complex and the substantia nigra are excitatory and presumably use glutamate as neurotransmitter (Kitai and Kita, '87; Smith and Parent, '88; Albin et al., '89).
The subthalamic input to the ventral pallidum might therefore be an important driving force of this part of the pallidal complex.

The present findings and the results of previous studies on the connections of the STh with the caudate nucleus of the primate (Parent and Smith, '87) indicate that functions of the STh are probably not restricted to the motor system, but also include the limbic and cognitive spheres of the brain.

The rather precise topographical arrangements in the connections of the STh with other parts of the basal ganglia might imply that the influence of a certain part of the STh remains restricted to those subdivisions of the striatopallidal system from which it receives its inputs.
Thus, judged purely on the basis of its connections, the involvement of the STh in limbic-motor integration is rather limited.
However, the projections from the medial STh to a lateral band of the globus pallidus may yet provide a way for limbic influences to reach the somatomotor system through the subthalamic nucleus.

In addition, the STh projections to the medial part of the globus pallidus and the medially adjacent region of the internal capsule may contact the numerous cholinergic neurons in this region (Mesulam, '83) that project to the prefrontal and motor cortices (Saper, '84; Luiten et al., '87).
